The Germans, for their part, unleashed 'Winter Storm' and the famous Manstein 'backhand blow' which did much to restore the situation. Within the scope of the EUROPA series of simulations from GDW, Uranus/Saturn attempts to allow gamers to explore the military possibilities open to both sides using components largely available. A number of major additions to the standard 'Fire in the East / Scorched Earth' (FITE/SE) rule set have been made, most of which should be seen as experimental and considered optional by anyone playing the scenario.

(from Introduction)
_________________________________________________

Note: For full 'Bro' rules experience, some Counters need to be fabricated and are not included.

Contents:

Ground rules, Part I - 6 pages
Air rules, Part II - 4 pages
Political rules, Part III - 2 pages
German OB - 3 pages
Soviet OB - 4 pages



4 Card Stock charts:

1 two sided (front & back), CRT along with 'Bro' Tables
1 German Off-map Display
1 Soviet Off-map Display
1 Examples of Bro Variant Counters
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: The Island of Treacherous Treasure
description:
The Island of Treacherous Treasure rewards players who can mix caution and daring. Decide how long to build the strength of your adventurer party as you explore the coast and gain vital information on the treacherous treasures, timing your expeditions into the island's heart to grab the treasure from under your rivals' noses.

As you explore the island you'll reveal traps and monsters and the treasures they guard.

Build and upgrade your party from the game's 13 unique adventurer cards, mixing their skills and strengths to give yourself an edge in your dangerous quest.

Once all the treasure has been plundered you'll discover who's holding the treacherous treasure and has been destroyed - although you may already know if you've explored for enough clues. Whoever is left alive with the most treasure is the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deduction, Hidden Victory Points, Modular Board

name: Clue Quest
description:
In Clue Quest players have hands of nine letter cards with which they form words. This is done one at a time; the active player plays cards face-down to form a word and then gives a crossword-style clue to it.

The other players then have to guess the word. When someone thinks they know the answer they announce this and then the other players have a short amount of time to also get it. (Guesses are written down.) All players with the correct answer score. The active player scores points based on the number of letters in the word, with a bonus if only one player gets the right answer. However, they are penalized if no one gets it.

The guessing players may ask for cards to be turned face-up, but the score for a correct answer is based on the number of remaining face-down cards.

name: Spellbounce
description:
Spellbounce is a cross between a word game and a tennis game. It is played on a board representing a tennis court with numbers along the service court lines and letters along the base and side lines.

To serve a player places their piece on a lettered space and a ball token on a number on the opposite service court line. They also place a letter disc along the net. A number and a letter die are rolled to determine the result of the shot, but generally the receiver will play a second letter disc. This procedure is repeated although starting with the third shot players must draw a card which may change how it is played.

The general object is to force your opponent to complete a word of at least four letters. If your opponent does this you win a game, and the first player to win six games wins the set, which corresponds to winning the overall game.

name: Diamond: The Game
description:
Diamond the Game Print and Play is a board game you can print at home, for 2-5 players that lasts between 20-30 minutes. It puts you and your family and friends directly in the role as a researcher at the Diamond Light Source, visiting different beamlines to make progress in a diverse range of scientific projects in Physics, Chemistry, Cultural Heritage, and more. As you travel around the synchrotron you will have to make the most of your experiments, as well as working with your fellow players, in order to be remembered as the most famous scientist!

Players move around the synchrotron, stopping at different beamlines that let them make progress in specific scientific disciplines. Once at a beamline, players perform an experiment, drawing cards that represent either successes or failure. They can draw as many cards as they want, but beware! If you draw 2 failure cards you must stop, and lose half of your successes. Once the experiment is finished, players can assign their successes to ongoing projects matching the discipline - once all requirements are met on a project it is completed, and will earn you fame. Once a set number of projects are completed, the game ends, and the scientist with the highest amount of fame wins!

Dr Mark Basham and Dr Claire Murray from Diamond Light Source and Dr Matthew Dunstan from the University of Cambridge created the game to showcase both the research performed at this world-leading facility, but also to give you first-hand experience of the different aspects of actually working in scientific research. Whether it is the variety of science that exists, the timely value of a vital collaboration, the disappointment of a failed experiment, or gratitude for the help from a friendly staff scientist, the game puts you directly in the action so you can make your own choices about what type of scientist you want to be.

—description from the designer
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Environmental, Print & Play

name: Corsica
description:
CORSICA: Two thousand years of Corsican history!

Corsica is an historical strategic boardgame for 4 players covering the hectic history of the beautiful island of Corsica.

In a typical game of Corsica, during 16 game rounds players will take command of the different nations that invaded and partially or fully controlled the island between 556 BC, when the Ancient Greeks first settled the spot of Aleria on the eastern coast, and 1796 AD, when the island finally fell under French control.

A typical game round of Corsica consists of the following phases:

The invasion phase (in which the new invaders attack and settle the island),
the internal struggle phase (in which all nations settled on Corsica fight each other),
and only during some specific turns, the Victory Points collection phase.


—description from the publisher

name: Meta
description:
Meta is an abstract game and in Italian it means goal. The term is also used in rugby to indicate the objective of a team: to make a meta. As in rugby, a player's goal is to bring a piece to a meta square on the opposite side. The board is a grid of 64 squares, plus 4 meta squares in the 4 corners. Each player has 8 pieces and 2 arrow-pieces. These 2, like head-prop in rugby, are powerful, but only pieces can make a meta!

—user summary

name: Lightning & Bolt
description:
Lightning & Bolt is a cooperative, tile matching game designed so players of varying ages or experience can play together. Players take on the roles of heroes or sidekicks. Their mission is to rescue the citizens of Midtown from the clutches of the evil Dr. Noxious.

Midtown is made up of randomly placed tiles creating a 3x3 grid (4x4 in a 4-5 player game). Players take turns moving around the city, flipping tiles, and finding matching citizens. Rescue all the citizen pairs and you win!

But, Dr. Noxious is also in the city, causing all kinds of mayhem. If you ever reveal Dr. Noxious' tile, all unmatched tiles are mixed (along with Dr. Noxious' tile) and the search continues. Reveal the Dr.'s tile three times and you lose.

But your team is up to the task! The hero’s mechanics (designed for a younger player) are fast, simple, light on rules, and high on fun. The sidekick’s mechanics (designed for more experienced players) are more complex and come with bigger arsenal of tools.

If hero and sidekick work together, using their unique abilities in tandem, Dr. Noxious had better watch out.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Matching, Memory

name: Conflict & Chaos: Vietnam 1965
description:
Conflict and Chaos: Vietnam 1965 is a historical strategic board game designed by James J Campbell and published by I Will Never Grow Up Games.

On 2 March, 1965, following an attack on a US Marine barracks at Pleiku, Operations Flaming Dart, Rolling Thunder and Arc Light commenced. This intense bombing campaign, which ultimately lasted three years, was intended to force North Vietnam to cease its support for the National Front for the Liberation of South Vietnam.

Ultimately, the US involvement in the war in Vietnam was ineffective. On 15 January, 1973, President Richard Nixon announced the suspension of US offensive action against North Vietnam. By wars end, the Vietnamese had been fighting foreign involvement or occupation for 116 years.

Take control of the nine major powers involved in one of the most controversial conflicts of all time. Can you change the course of history?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Force Commitment, Hidden Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game

name: The Spiritual Path
description:
The Spiritual Path is a boardgame of Spiritual Ascension uniting the Paths of Science, Religion, Philosophy & Occult Mysticism.

Players work to balance Coin of the Realm as they ascend the 3 Planes (Physical, Astral & Mental) while gaining 'knowledge & experience' upon many different Paths.

Players will encounter challenges on LIFE Cards, including rare Magic and Siddhi cards, as well as the Teachers of the Middle Pillar, Crisis Points, Dark Nights of the Soul and more.

Players who are able to open all 9 Petals in the Egoic Lotus are free to walk the Rainbow Bridge and win the game!

—description from the publisher

name: The War for Heaven and Earth
description:
The War for Heaven and Earth is a board game that pits the forces of Light versus the forces of Darkness. Players battle upon a huge map of Earth (Gaia) and move between the continents via Ports.

Players begin with an Ascended Master who creates Magicians and Knights who must all work to 'align the territorial planes' in Body, Mind & Spirit.

Players employ Strategy Cards and can simultaneously combine attacks from many squares upon one or more Planes, resulting in the potentially massive gain or loss of Energetic Units.

Players who control the greatest number of 'fully aligned' Territories when the 'Event' card is drawn win the game!

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Dice, Religious, Wargame

name: Conspiracy Theories!
description:
Conspiracy Theories is a card game that challenges players to link conspiracies into theories to bring disclosure to the world!


DRAW CONSPIRACY CARDS to simulate the endless hours of research required to become acquainted with the evidence.
GROUP BY CATEGORY: Study the Conspiracies to discover the hidden web linking them together by Category.
FORM A THEORY: Link 3 or more Conspiracies and play the Leading Theory.
BUMP THE LEADER: Bump the Leading Theory by producing even more evidence.
Use SMEAR CAMPAIGN CARDS *to muddy the water around a colleague.
Use DEBUNK CARDS *to permanently disprove a Category narrowing the search.
ACCUSE a colleague of *SUPPRESSING EVIDENCE *if you suspect that they hold the Debunk card to their own Theory.


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Economic, Educational, Environmental, Political
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction

name: Clash Of Eagles, The German Two-Front War of 1939
description:
Clash of Eagles combines Europa games 'Fall of France' (FoF) and 'Case White' (CW). This scenario allows Europa Buffs to explore a historical 'what-if:'

"What would have happened if the West had been more aggressive while the Wehrmacht was invading Poland?"

This scenario mainly uses rules from FITE/SE (Fire-in-the-East & Scorched Earth) and adds a number of optional 'Bro' rules for added enjoyment. Certain charts and Orders-of-Battle(OB's) are also needed from FoF and CW. It further requires a rather extensive collection of other Europa items, like specific issues of Bill Stone's ETO fanzine for updated OB's for specific combatants.


Note: For full 'Bro' rules experience, some counters need to be fabricated and are not included.


Contents:

Clash of Eagles ground rules, Part I - 8 pages
Clash of Eagles air rules, Part II - 4 pages
Clash of Eagles naval rules, Part III - 0 pages (not used)
Clash of Eagles political rules, Part IV - 4 pages
Clash of Eagles German OB, Part V - 3 pages
Clash of Eagles Allied OB, Part VI - 6 pages

5 Card Stock Charts:

2 x Bro rules aircraft counters in B&W
1 x 1 page, two sided (front & back), CRT along with 'Bro' Tables
1 x German Off-map Display
1 x Allies Off-map Display
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Blood Red Skies: Ace Pilot – Johnny Red
description:
Feature your rogue British pilot and ACE Johnny Red in his Hurricane alongside the rough and ready Soviet 5th air brigade squadron known as the ‘the Falcons’ - in this special edition you'll even get Johnny in 28mm FREE!

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Edge of Tomorrow (All You Need Is Kill): The Board Game
description:
Earth is under attack and its up to you or you and your team to find and stop the Omega. Every day you die to only fight the same battle over and over again but with the knowledge of what is to come. Acquire the skills, weapons and knowledge to survive and you can find the Omega, stop the loop and save the day.

Edge of tomorrow is 1 to 4 player Deck building, exploration and memory game. Using some core deck building mechanics and putting a twist on exploration games, Edge of tomorrow brings alive the idea of not only buffing yourself up but learning your surrounding and strategically planning your plays. Each hand is a new life so make of it what you can.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Memory, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Memory, Modular Board, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Blood Red Skies: German Ace Pilot – Erich Hartmann
description:
Erich Alfred Hartmann (19 April 1922 – 20 September 1993) was the most successful fighter ace in the history of aerial warfare. He was credited with 352 Allied aircraft downed - of which 350 were Soviet and 2 American over the course of WW2. This was despite 16 separate instances of being forced to crash land his fighter - either due to mechanical failure or to damage incurred from the debris of enemy aircraft he himself had shot down.

Prior to the War he was a glider pilot, but joined the Luftwaffe in 1940 and had completed his training by 1942. Posted to Jagdgeschwader 52, a veteran wing on the Eastern front, he benefitted from the supervision of some of the Luftwaffe's most experienced pilots, flying the Messerschmitt BF109G.

As his reputation developed he gained the nickname Cherniy Chort ("Black Devil"), both because of his skill and his aircraft's paint scheme. Hartmann was greatly decorated for his achievements, ultimately receiving the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves, Swords and Diamonds on 25th August 1944 having achieved 301 aerial victories. This was, at the time, Germany's highest military decoration.

Hartmann's final victory came at midday on 8 May 1945, hours before the German surrender. Turned over to the Red Army, he was tried on war crimes and sentenced to 20 years of imprisonment. He was released in 1955 and posthumously released of all charges (in 1997).

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Blood Red Skies: US Ace Pilot – 'Gabby' Gabreski
description:
"Gabby" Gabreski was the top USAAF fighter ace over Europe during World War II and would go on to become an Ace of the Korean War (one of only 7 US pilots to become an Ace in two different wars) and a Colonel during his 26 years of military service. He was the son of Polish immigrants to Pennsylvania. Abandoning his second year at Notre-Dame University, Gabreski enlisted in the USAAF, though was not a particularly successful trainee.

Trained on the P-36 and P-40, Gabreski began flying sorties in the wake of Pearl Harbour to intercept further Japanese attacks, though they had withdrawn. Concerned that the US lacked experienced pilots, Gabreski volunteered and was accepted (as a Captain) on RAF duty with Polish pilots of No. 315 squadron. It was here he learnt the art of staying calm in combat.

On February 27, 1943, Gabreski became part of the 56th Fighter Group, flying the Republic P-47C Thunderbolt, assigned to the 61st Fighter Squadron, and despite resentment from his fellow pilots he was soon elevated to Major and took command of the Squadron on June 9th. In the cockpit of a Thunderbolt in the European theatre, Gabreski achieved 28 aerial victories, a total never surpassed in the theatre by U.S pilots engaged with the Luftwaffe. On June 20, 1944, Gabreski had achieved the 300 hours required flight time, but rather than go home (for his wedding) he took one more mission. Following damage to his propellers after a strafing run on a Luftwaffe airfield, he was forced to crash land. He managed to evade capture for 5 days before being sent to Stalag Luft.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Blood Red Skies: Japanese Ace Pilot – Yozo Tsuboi
description:
Yozo Tsuboi, was Japans only Raiden Ace claiming 5.5 victories in this aircraft whilst serving with the 302nd Kokutai (302nd Naval Air Group).

He lost his last battle when taking on a formidably armed F-13A reconnaissance aircraft, (a redesignated version of the B-29 bomber) 1st April 1945.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Buzzy Buzziness
description:
The spring is here and everything has awoken. You represent worker honeybees which are flying through fields in search off the best flowers to pick up pollen and bring it back to their hive. The bee who manages to best fulfill its Queen Bee's orders will be awarded the title of the Best Honey Bee and win the game.

Buzzy Buzziness is a grid-movement game for 2-5 players where you represent bees fulfilling your Queen’s orders. You must be the first to bring the right type of flower pollen to complete certain orders, claiming victory points (VPs) and small bonuses from it. At the end of the game, worker bee with the most VPs will be the winner.

—description from the designer
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Closed Drafting, Grid Movement, Hidden Victory Points, Modular Board, Movement Points

name: Discover Omaha
description:
Discover Omaha is a simple dice-rolling game, in which players started at Eppley and rolled their way through the city. The board resembled Monopoly and was geographically faithful-ish to Omaha.

It is one of the first modern board games created by black game designers. The rules are designed so that people will become familiar with Omaha. The purpose of the game was to learn the city's history and notable locations. Locations include the Orpheum Theater, Rosenblatt Stadium, Henry Doorly Zoo, Civic Auditorium, Bank of Florence, Central High School, Joslyn Art Museum, Peony Park, Boystown, Southroads, Union Stock Yards, Crossroads, Fort Calhoun, Hummel Park, Great Plains Black Museum, Ak-Sar-Ben and many more. First one to Central Park Mall won.

—user summary

name: Red Fred
description:
Red Fred is a trick-taking game for three players (the rules state that it can be modified for other numbers, but do not give specifics).

A standard 52-card deck is dealt into four 13-card hands - one for each player and one which is left in a face-down dummy stack to the left of the dealer. Players then freely bid for the number of tricks they will take, beginning with the dealer and proceeding counter-clockwise (i.e., in the reverse of the play order).

The dummy stack leads to every trick - the top card is turned over. Suit must be followed and there is no trump.

Each player scores points based on how many tricks they took, with three tricks being worth no points and other numbers being more valuable the further they are from three. In addition a five-point bonus is scored for making one's bid.

name: Blood Red Skies: British Ace Pilot – Johnny Johnson
description:
While Johnnie Johnson missed the Battle of France and Battle of Britain due to a sporting injury, he went on to become the most successful RAF pilot against the Fw 190, destroying 20.

He was also the highest scoring western fighter ace against the Luftwaffe in general.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Politics!: The Card Game
description:
Politics! The Card Game is an exciting new triangular deck game of getting the most support possible from as many groups as possible. Politics! The Card Game is bias-free, nonpartisan fun for the whole family. Politics! The Card Game was created by two-time Senate candidate Jensen Bohren during his initial 2018 run for Senate in Mississippi.

The basics of the game are as follows.
The first turn, every player puts a card from their hand face down, then reveal at the same time. The lowest unpaired card takes the cards into their score pile, then plays a card face-up, The rest of the players play their next cards face up in clockwise order. This repeats until all hands are empty.

If a round can't be scored, another round is played starting with the person who played first last round. Once a round is won, the winning player takes all the cards into their score pile.

Once hands are empty, the player with the lowest score wins. Scoring is based on how many of each number is in the score pile.

name: Superhero Gladiators
description:
Superhero Gladiators is a game about superheroes fighting in an arena. It is for two or more players, who must be old enough to do some subtraction. Each arena combat takes five to thirty minutes.

Because Superhero Gladiators is free, fun, strategic, and quick to play it is an great way to test if you (or your kids) enjoy games involving combat with miniatures.

Besides these rules, players need a token for each superhero, either a "battlemap" (we use Flip-Mats) or some hexagon paper, a pencil, two 20-sided dice, either index cards or copies of the character sheet below, and perhaps a calculator.

Superhero Gladiators was inspired by the role-playing game named Champions.

—description from the publisher

name: Locked Adventures: Der Fall
description:
Case I - The Sanna Virtanna's Disappearance

You are a team of investigative journalists and one day you receive a mysterious phone call: 17-year-old Finn Sanna Virtannen has disappeared. You should solve this case in Ristijärvi, a small town in the far north of Finland.

name: Locked Adventures: Der Fall II
description:
Case II - The Secret of Anders Berglund

A mysterious accident. After the press hype in the Virtannen case, this time you get a call from the wife of journalist Anders Berglund: Anders had an accident and has been in a coma ever since. His wife tells you that Anders had behaved very strangely in the days before and that she would not get rid of the feeling that something was wrong. You sense a tricky case and head to Stockholm to get to the bottom of it.

name: Locked Adventures: Ein magischer Fall
description:
A magical case - mysterious sleep in the magic school

You are sitting in the lounge when the door suddenly swings open and your world is turned upside down: Jamie, your best friend, has fallen into a mysterious sleep that is slowly spreading out in your magical school. Will Jamie ever wake up again?

More information in the product description. Just click on the title or the picture.

name: Ätsch: reingefallen
description:
Each player has to get four pawns from start to finish. Movement is determined by a die. On the roll of a "1" a pawn gets from the start to space 1 to get into the race. Before moving each player has to adjust the slide table according to the result of his roll. Pawns falling into the holes are eliminated from the game. If a pawn would move onto a hole it is put back on the starting space instead. The first player to get the most pawns to the finish wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Blood Red Skies: Polikarpov I-16 Squadron
description:
In-game, you'll find these little wasps to be incredibly useful - field a swarm of low-cost, agile fighters with a low minimum move which will allow you to out turn faster-moving aircraft and set up the perfect attack!

A small squadron of these Polikarpov I-16 could support a group Yak-1s or Mig-3s, acting as a second line to swoop down on anything that should slip through after the first engagement.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Blood Red Skies: Mikotan Gurevich MiG-3 Squadron
description:
While the MiG-3 has the Sluggish trait, it is a serviceable frontline fighter with decent mobility conferred by the Great Dive trait, with an agility and firepower score equal to that of the early war Bf109's it's most likely to come into contact with.

A squadron of these could easily support Yak-1s or I-16s without too much trouble.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: The Path of Initiation
description:
The Path of Initiation is a role-playing board game of Spiritual Evolution upon the Greath Wheel of Life & Death!

Players begin as a young Ego/Personality and move their Avatars around the gameboard and their Soul-Stones up the Kabbalistic 'Tree of Life.'

Players are tasked with resolving Life Lessons using the Special Powers of their 'class' while demonstrating knowledge of the 7 Hermetic Principles.

Other players role-play the Higher Self and the Lords of Karma and together reward the player with the Karma, Polarity & Experience Points to gain Initiation and win the game!

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Ancient, Dice, Educational, Party Game, Religious
mechanics: Acting, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hidden Roles, Voting

name: Superpuzzle
description:
Superpuzzle contains two sets of pieces in different colors. Each set consists of 24 pieces: 12 rectangles and 12 rectangles with one corner cut off.

The game also contains a book of 60 puzzles, each of which is a shape that can be made with one set of pieces. If played by two players each can take one set of pieces and try to be the first to complete the puzzle.

name: Times Table Trio
description:
Times Table Trio contains two decks of 60 cards each; each deck contains the 58 unique numbers appearing in the multiplication tables up to 12, plus two jokers. The rules recommend using one deck with two or three players and two with more, but experienced players may always use two decks.

Each player is dealt 9 or 12 cards (12 being more challenging) and attempts to make sets of three cards (trios) which are consecutive multiples of the same number, e.g. 2-4-6 or 55-66-77. This is done via standard Rummy-style play - a player draws the top card of the deck or discard pile and then discards a card. If a joker is used in a trio a player holding the card it is representing may also swap that for the joker.

Completed trios are placed face-up on the table. Players may lay off cards on any trio to form longer sequences, and may also form new trios in different directions.

name: Card Buluch
description:
Card Buluch is played with a standard 52-card deck and a score card with ten boxes for each player.

On their turn a player turns over cards from the deck until they decide to stop or bust by revealing an ace or a two. If they don't bust they then select one of the boxes they have not used yet and score their revealed cards according to it. E.g. in box 1 they score if they have more red than black cards, in box 9 they score if they have a sequence of five cards, etc. If they cannot score or if they bust they must place an X in a box.

The game ends after both players have had ten turns.

name: Bluff
description:
Bluff uses a standard 52-deck plus a joker. It is played in a sequence of hands, each using a single suit plus the joker.

In each hand the 14 cards are dealt evenly to the two players and the dealer begins by playing a card face-down and stating what it is, but they may lie about it. The other player plays a card and the two are compared; the high card wins the trick. The joker is the highest card but is beaten by the ace (which is otherwise low). The winner leads to the next trick.

In the second through fourth hands the winner of the previous hand deals and then may exchange hands with the other player before leading to the first trick.

Play continues either until the end of the fourth hand, in which case the winner of that hand wins the game, or until a player reaches 100 points. In the latter case players score from one to four points per excess trick, depending on the hand. The whole cycle restarts with the fifth hand.

name: コタツのなかからでたくない (I don't wanna leave kotatsu)
description:
In コタツのなかからでたくない (I don’t wanna leave kotatsu), players want to both stay warm in the kotatsu, but also eat many satsuma oranges. However, there are chores to be done, and you may be able to earn oranges by doing them.

After constructing the game's kotatsu, the players slip their player piece partially inside. A player privately looks at the top tile from a deck of 16 chores, and places a number of oranges from a supply on the kotatsu; this number may be more or less than the value of the tile.

All players then discuss if they will leave the kotatsu to perform the chore. Once discussion is complete, the players simultaneously remove their player piece or leave it, and afterwards the tile is revealed. If the number of oranges placed on the kotatsu is less than that shown on the tile, the player(s) who performed the chore split the pot as evenly as possible. However, if the number of oranges placed on the kotatsu is greater than the value of the tile, the player(s) who performed the chore only split the oranges up to the value of the tile.

In either case, any remaining oranges are split as evenly as possible among the players who stayed in the kotatsu!

The tile is set aside face up; the lead player moves clockwise; and play continues. The game ends when the supply of oranges is exhausted, and the player with the most wins.
publishers: Shime-Shime Games (シメシメゲームズ)

name: Cruel Seas: HMS Campbeltown
description:
Originally a US destroyer, HMS Campbeltown was transferred to the Royal Navy as part of the Destroyers for Bases agreement after the outset of World War Two. She was arguably the most famous of these ships due to her role in Operation Chariot in 1942.

Though she saw a brief service with the Royal Netherlands Navy, her most famed action was that against the dry dock of St Nazaire. This facility was the World’s largest dry-dock, and provided a site of vital strategic interest to both Allies and Axis, offering a gateway to the Atlantic and large enough to house the mighty Tirpitz and Bismarck. Should they have been unleashed upon Atlantic convoy shipping, the war effort will have suffered incredibly.

With the dock well into an estuary and capital ship involvement an impossibility, a daring plan was concocted. HMS Campbeltown would be disguised as a German ship and, along with a flotilla, would be laden with explosives and used as a ram against the dock gates. Simultaneously, the flotilla would disgorge their loads of British Commandos to sow chaos amongst the Kriegsmarine defenders. The vessels and their payloads of munitions and men were seen as expendable, such was the critical nature of this mission.

Though both Allied and Axis losses were heavy the mission was a complete success – with the dry-dock knocked out of action for the duration of the war, and the threat of the Tirpitz sailing the Atlantic never materializing.

Contains 1 ship. Within the pages of Close Quarters! the latest supplement for Cruel Seas, you’ll find rules and a scenario for re-enacting the daring St Nazaire raid on the tabletop.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Movement Template, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Total vermöbelt
description:
The players have to move their meeple into the house and deliver furniture into the rooms. Movement is determinated by a die. If a meeple gets on a yellow space he gets to draw an action card. Many of themm allow to place furniture into a room. If a meeple lands on a red space the next player may return a already placed piece of furniture to the meeples player.

The first player who leaves the house after placing all of his furniture wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fire When Ready
description:
NAVAL WARGAMES RULES FOR PRE-DREADNOUGHT ACTIONS

Fire When Ready covers actions with pre-dreadnoughts. They come with a set of rules for creating your game statistics for your vessels using published sources such as "Jane’s" or "Conway’s".

The rules features an choice of game systems. The "Duel" Game is intended for use with a small number of ships and each ship has a captain and crew generated individually. The "Battle" system is for large battles such as Tsushima and ships operate in formations, each of which has a Commander and ships' crew ratings are generated for a formation.

There are alternative gunnery systems offering simultaneous effects (which can be used with the "Duel" Game) or sequential effects based on initiative, in which shooting follows in order of initiative (highest scores shoot first) and where damage is applied immediately (this can be used in either game system).

The gunnery rules include the effects of "crossing the T" and other features. It is now possible to achieve significant amounts of damage and multiple special hits.

There are 10 scenarios and ready calculated ship data is provided so you can sit down and play any of them.

Recommended scale: 1/1200 to 1/3000
Complexity: 6/10

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Will-To-Win Tennis
description: A tennis themed board game.

name: Chosen Men & Voltigeurs
description:
Chosen Men & Voltigeurs was created to simulate small unit skirmishes and small scale battles in the Napoleonic era.
It is designed to let new players come up to speed quickly but let veteran players squeeze the last bit of performance out of their fighting units.
Depending on the scenario, you can simulate companies, battalions or regiments and by adjusting unit combat values can represent units from any nationality in the Napoleonic era.
Special events make the flow of the battle unpredictable and allow even a lost cause to triumph with solid play.... and a little luck and pluck!

Features:

Simulate engagements from the popular Sharpe's Rifles series...
Man-to-man or larger unit combat...
Easy to play with general gaming knowledge...
Adjustable combat values for simulating different nationalities and periods in the Napoleonic era...
Random order of movement and firing...
Special characters, special weapons and special events from fire or hand-to-hand combat...
Berserk units...
Unique artillery scatter and bounce & roll rules...


—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Turn Order: Random

name: Master the Five
description:
Master the Five is a cooperative hand-management card game for 4-5 players.

One player will take on the role of a master, and all other players will initially take on the role of apprentices eagerly seeking to learn magic. To win, all apprentices must graduate to become masters by casting spells and gaining power in each of five different magic disciplines. However, apprentices are inexperienced and foolhardy with spells, casting uncanny incantations that tend to do more harm than good. If any player dies, all players lose.
Therefore, masters will try and protect themselves and others by countering incoming spells and planning powerful sorcery spells. Don't forget that so much spell power in one place can cause horrible electrical storms, so strategize as a group to win as quickly and efficiently as possible!

—description from the designer

name: Ambush
description:
Ambush is played with two copies of a small grid of triangles. Players start at opposite ends of the grid and move one space a turn; the spaces are the vertices.

One player's copy of the grid is visible to both players (this player is the "Scout"). The other player's copy is hidden; this player moves first (and is the "Indian").

The object of the openly-moving player is to reach the opposite end of the grid. The object of the other player is to be in the space that the openly-moving player enters, in which case he is ambushed and loses. The hidden player may not move into the other player's space.

name: Devil's Golf
description:
Devil's Golf is played on a course of 9 or 18 holes marked on a table top or other large flat surface (this can be done non-destructively e.g. with taped paper circles). A starting point is also designated.

The game is played in partnerships. The first player is followed by an opponent and so on.

Players use marked coins as balls and small lengths of wood as clubs. The object is of course to get the ball into the next hole. However, hitting another player's ball (even your partner's) gets a player another turn, which is an important part of the game. Finishing a hole also gives a player another turn.

A partnership wins when both players complete the last hole.

name: Snakes
description:
Snakes is played on an 8x8 board with snake heads adjacent to the four middle squares of two of the edges and snake tails adjacent to the same squares on the other edges. The heads and tails come in four different colors.

There are 48 tiles in the game, divided into four identical sets. Each set has snake sections (heads, middles, and tails) in all the colors, and has a symbol to distinguish players. (It is not clear how tiles are distributed with fewer than four players.)

The first player plays in one of the four central squares and after that players must play adjacent to a tile or one of the pre-printed heads or tails. Colors must be matched. A snake cannot have two heads or two tails.

If a player cannot play a tile the next player able to play removes one of the blocked player's tiles and gives it back to them. A 2x2 block of tiles from the same player cannot be removed.

The winner is the first to play all their tiles.

name: Car Chase
description:
Be the first player to race your car round the track and back home again.
You must decide whether to move your car or add more track to the circuit. Pick your route home carefully avoiding obstacles in your path.
Contains 24 Track pieces to build as you go. Decide on the route. Never the same game twice.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Candles & Cakes: The Party Board Game
description:
This is a bright and easy-to-learn roll-and-move children's game. Players race each other to be the first to reach a party, but they can't attend it until they've picked up everything they need first

First of all, they'll need to find a cake, a candle and a present, all in the same colour scheme, which is trickier than it sounds. This is achieved by landing on the appropriate space and drawing cards, with the goal being to create a full set of items in the same colour. They can also land on someone else to pinch the piece they need. On top of that, they'll also need to find an invitation- best beware of the blanks!

Chance cards add a twist to proceedings, with some helping and some hindering progress. A card could launch you just where you need to go to secure that last item, or they could make you wear the dreaded "silly hat", which prevents you from picking up any items at all.

Candles and Cakes is a simple game which relies more on chance than strategy, but which has colourful graphics, a novel jigsaw-style board, and scope for up to 8 players. Suitable for kids aged 6 and above.
mechanics: Matching, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rosette
description:
Rosette is a translation of Go to a hexagonal grid. Unlike some other hexagonal versions of Go, in this one pieces are placed on the vertices of the hexes, not the hexes themselves, so each stone has only three neighbors.

The board is a hexagonal grid in the shape of a hexagon, with seven hexagons on each side. This contains 294 vertices.

All the rules of Go apply with one addition: a hexagon with all the vertices occupied by stones of one color (called a rosette) cannot be captured.

name: Forts
description:
Forts is a game similar to Battleship. Each player has two copies of a grid numbered 1-10 along one axis and A-J along the other. One grid is used to track one's own plays and the other the opponent's plays.

Before the game begins each player places three forts - 3x3 squares - on their grid. The forts cannot touch at all, even at the corners.

A turn consists of stating an outside square to start at and a direction to cross the grid in (this may be diagonal). Every space in this line is hit and the target player states how many of their forts were hit.

When a player thinks they know the locations of the opposing forts they announce this as their turn: if they can correctly name the center squares of the forts they win, otherwise they lose.

name: Espionage
description:
Espionage is a card-based deduction game played on a map of Britain divided into 24 numbered areas plus London. There is a card for each numbered area, one of which is removed at the start of the game; naturally the object is to identify this card.

The remaining cards plus a foreign agent card (and with five players an MI5 card) are dealt out to the players. On a turn a player generally moves to an adjacent area and then may ask another player whether they have a specific card or a card for anywhere in one region. (The map is divided into six colored regions.) The player holding the foreign agent card may lie.

There are a few airports on the board so to move more quickly an agent may move to one and then move along the arrows to get to another airport.

There are at most 24 rounds in the game; after each round a clock hand is moved. Where the clock hand is determines the allowed moves, e.g. in the early hours only specific questions may be asked, near the end the foreign agent may not lie, etc.

name: Jay and Silent Bob Big Fat Card-On Game
description:
A Homegrown Card Game from Jay and Silent Bob! Jay and Silent Bob Big Fat Card-On Game, was created in a convenience store parking lot, your mission is to make solid yet cringeworthy decisions and engage in verbal battle.

Draw and pair cards side by side, roll the dice to determine the play mode and have a blast. Snootchie Bootchies!

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Dice, Humor, Mature / Adult, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Science Fiction

name: Fugitive
description:
Fugitive is played on a board of the players' devising which is a network of locations connected by lines; it is suggested that 50-60 locations be used. Locations can be connected to two, three, or four other locations.

In each round one or more players are fugitives and the other players are hunters; each has a piece on the board. Each turn everyone writes down their next destination, which can be up to three locations away. The fugitives move first and then the hunters; if a fugitive ends up on the same location as a hunter they are captured. The locations visited by hunters are marked with counters and fugitives may never pass through a counter.

The fugitive player(s) score points for visiting locations. The round ends when all fugitives have been captured, and enough rounds need to be played to give each player the same number of turns as a fugitive, since the hunters do not score.

(The game can be played by more than six - no maximum is actually given.)

name: Jay and Silent Bob Smell My Finger Game
description:
Compete with your friends by picking scents of your choice, placing them in the fingers, battling and earning points for smelling and using your aromatic intellect to answer confusing questions. Gain points for guessing correctly, lose points for wrong guesses. Be the first player to earn 10 points to win.

Components:
12 wearable fingers, 52 hint cards, 10 smell off cards.

name: Schrödinger's Castle
description:
This game combines scientific and adventurous aspects. The game idea is based on the famous thought experiment formulated by the Austrian theoretical physicist Erwin Schrödinger. The experiment describes a cat that turns out to be both alive and dead due to circumstances and formalism of quantum mechanics. This unusual state makes the Schrödinger's cat widely popular in contemporary mainstream culture.

The goal of the game is to save the Schrödinger's cat from inhumane experiments. Notwithstanding the long and complicated story of the cat, the basic rules are simple enough to understand by every person, even if he or she is unfamiliar with the paradox of the Schrödinger's cat. Nonetheless, science enthusiasts will definitely notice that the rules contain multiple allusions to the quantum mechanical world view.

The game is represented as a labyrinth with the changing structure - the Schrödinger's castle. The winner is the player who managed to find the Schrodinger's cat in the labyrinth and led it to his starting point. The distinctive feature of the game is that all players can build and change the structure of the labyrinth the way they want. Specially elaborated system of action cards used on each player's turn is also of interest. Despite the randomness factor during a turn, it allows players to develop a unique long-term strategy.

The labyrinth consists of 19 wooden hexagonal elements - the halls of Schrödinger's castle. The halls contain passageways connecting their different sides. At the beginning of the game, all halls are turned upside down and are not visible to players. During his turn, each player can move around the castle, gradually opening the halls and joining the passages as it suits him. However, as soon as a player leaves any hall, this hall is turned over, and the next player who comes to this hall will be able to open it in a convenient way.

The turns are made by playing action cards (3 cards per turn). These cards allow you to move around the castle, prevent the empty halls from closing, rotate open halls and rearrange closed ones, open locked doors, and arrange baits for Schrödinger's cat. At the end of the turn, the player collects up to 3 new cards. The game does not contain direct conflict between players, all interactions take place through the restructuring of a common labyrinth. Victory conditions depend on whether Schrödinger's cat is alive or dead, this is also decided by the players during the game.

The game has a colourful minimalistic design. The game board is made of embossed wooden elements. Game elements do not contain any text - all the necessary information is contained in the form of images. The combination of simple rules and richness of game situations resembles chess, however, unlike the latter, the game contains a significant role of chance in the gameplay.

-description from designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Hexagon Grid, Memory, Tile Placement

name: Aztec Football
description:
Aztec Football is a 2-player game where two teams of warriors play a match against one another to see who can make the most goals and earn the most points. Each team has four warriors of different strengths which will move on to the field. Once on the field, they will try to position themselves so they can maneuver the four colored boulders by pushing and pulling them around the field using their strength. Each of the colored boulders will have a value and you must use a combined strength greater than the value of the boulder to be able to move it. Be careful where your opponent is, he can use one of his warriors to knock one of your warriors off the field. The team that is able to push a colored boulder into their goal will earn the point value of that boulder. The winning team will be the one who can obtain the most points from the highest value boulders and the losing team will be sacrificed to the Gods.

-description from designer
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Different Dice Movement, Grid Movement

name: Qui Paire Gagne: Carte Plato
description:
Promo Card included in Plato 87 from June 2016.

Shows a 'serving tray' (plateau in french) to get e relation to the Plato magazine.

The card is shuffled into the normal deck.

name: The Derby Day
description:
The Derby Day is a gambling game for any reasonable number of players (10 was chosen as an arbitrary maximum).

The game is played on a board with five lanes for horses, a betting area, and an odds area. Each horse has several possible starting positions (determined by the bookmaker) and each has a different number of spaces in its lane.

After odds are set for a race two dice are thrown and the horse corresponding to the higher die is moved one space, or two if doubles are rolled. The horses with higher numbers have more spaces to cover.

At any given time one player is the bookmaker. Before each race they set the odds, which can be 4-1 for all horses or 2-1, 3-1, 4-1, 5-1, and 6-1 assigned as they wish. They also choose where the horses start - the normal start, the handicap start behind this, or even ahead of the normal start. The other players then bet and after the race is over bets are paid off.

name: Crosso
description:
Crosso is played on a square grid at least 5x5 in size. Players take turns entering their symbols (e.g. X and O) in empty spaces. If the grid side is an odd number then one space will be left empty so each player has the same number of turns.

The starting player is called the attacker and is the only one who scores; they score for each row, column, or major diagonal with at least three of the same symbol together, regardless of whose symbol it is. The more symbols the more they score.

Since only one player scores the game needs to be played an even number of times, reversing positions each time.

name: Chains
description:
Chains is played on a square grid at least 5x5 in size. Players take turns entering their symbols (e.g. X and O) in empty spaces. If the grid side is an odd number then one space will be left empty so each player has the same number of turns.

After the grid is complete each player scores in two ways. They score one point for each of their symbols in their longest chain of symbols (i.e. the longest path of their symbols that can be traced without backtracking). They also score one point for each adjacent pair of their symbols. A symbol can belong to more than one pair and to pairs as well as the longest chain. Diagonal adjacency doesn't count for anything.

name: Octagon
description:
Octagon is ideally played with a 40-card deck containing six suits; the cards are numbered 1-12 but the suits have different numbers of cards, e.g. the blue suit consists of 1, 6, 7, and 12.

Most of the cards are shuffled and dealt into eight face-down piles of four cards each, in the form of an octagon. The blue cards and matching black cards are placed face-up on top of these as the dealer chooses.

A turn consists of picking up a stack of cards, revealing them, and then placing them on successive stacks in clockwise order. If a stack has just one or two cards in it the top card can be captured by placing a card of the same rank on it. There are a few additional rules, e.g. when capturing counterclockwise moves may be made.

At the end of the round captured cards are scored; different suits score differently, e.g. the blue cards are 10 points each, black cards (the longest suit) score only for the player with the most, red cards score for sequences, etc.

Four players play in partnerships; while the rules technically allow for play by four or five individuals, only three play at a time.

Rules are provided to allow play with a standard deck.

name: Amazon Peril
description:
During the heydey of Amazonian exploration of the 1930s, you are a character drawn to the Amazonian jungle with your own personal agenda to be there (Anthropologist, Archeologist, Big Game Hunter, Botanist, Bush Pilot, Cartographer, Journalist or Treasure Seeker), with each character offering its own unique traits and skills.

You find yourself on a flight to a jumping off point in the jungle, along with other characters with their own reasons pulling them to this part of the world. Unfortunately, soon after take-off, the plane engine gives out and the pilot is forced to make an emergency landing in the middle of the jungle. Now, stranded in the jungle how will you – and your companions who you don’t know – survive and escape? Can you trust them? Will you work together or splinter off on your own? The choice is yours.

In Amazon Peril, you and your companions will begin the game, lost somewhere in the jungle and you will have to use your skills to explore, survive and escape the jungle by finding the airstrip you left from. Each round is a day; you’ll make plans in the morning, in the afternoon you’ll execute them and in the evening you’ll assess your thirst, hunger and health and prepare for the next day.

Each morning, choose from these core actions: camping for the day (where you try to rest up and heal), scouting (where you’ll cautiously explore the jungle around you) and exploring (where you’ll move through the jungle, placing and revealing new tiles that can lead to many dangerous and exciting outcomes; maybe you’ll stumble across an indigenous tribe, find ancient ruins or encounter dangerous wildlife).

You may choose to go it alone for riskier encounters but more rewards; or journey in groups to lessen the risk but split the rewards. But be careful; desperate circumstances can bring out the worst in people. You might be tempted to steal supplies from your companions at night or they might steal from you!

As you journey through the jungle, you can gain or lose renown points for the actions you take and the discoveries you make. It isn’t just about survival; those who survive will have tales to tell and deeds to boast of - and whomever has the most renown points when the airstrip is finally revealed will win the game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action/Event, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Hidden Victory Points, Semi-Cooperative Game, Tile Placement

name: Entkommen!: Der gefangene Geheimagent
description:
The world hour of Sarajevo. Can you change the course of the world?

A secret organization that plans to murder the heir to the throne.

A secret agent trapped in a dungeon.

Secret codes, closed doors, puzzles for experts.

You only have 60 minutes to prevent an assassination attempt. Can you "ESCAPE" in time?

The escape game on the go - for one or more players.

Volume 2 of the ESCAPE series.

—description from the publisher (translated)
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Elapsed Real Time Ending

name: Perds pas le Nord!
description:
A trivia game with questions about the North of France.

Edited by the Chamber of commerce of Nord-Pas de Calais region with the sponsorship of 10 companies.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Battleground Brawl
description:
Battleground Brawl is a tabletop, platform fighting game that pits fighters (players) against each other in an attempt to either deplete the opponents health, or knock them off of the play area, in order to score points.

The play area consists of a board with a grid. This grid is the guide for where platforms and players can be placed. To set up the game, players agree on the placement of the platform pieces and then choose where to place their fighters. For round 1, the player with the lowest health starts, and each subsequent round the "first player" moves clockwise. Each round, players must first take it in turns, going clockwise from the "first player", to move their fighters according to their movement field. If a player moves adjacent to another player, then that player is not allowed to move in this turn, as they are deemed to be engaged in battle.

Once all players that can move, have moved, then the combat phase begins. Each player plays a card face-down from their hand and chooses a target opponent. A hand consists of 5 cards drawn from that players deck. A deck consists of a number of cards available to each fighter.

Once every player has played a card face down and declared a target, flip the cards and resolve them in the same order as movement in that round. Some cards may be played out of order, as a reaction to other cards, for example: If Player 1 targets Player 4 with an attack card, but Player 4 played a dodge card, then Player 4 resolves this action before Players 2 and 3. If Player 2 (and/or 3) also targeted Player 4, they target that players previous location and therefore Player 4 dodges all attacks simultaneously, they do not target the new location.

Once all actions have been resolved and health deducted/added where appropriate, the "first player" switches clockwise and the next round begins. Discard previously played cards and draw your hand back up to 5 cards. Declare your movement (if applicable), then your targets, then play your next card, and repeat.

—description from the designer

name: Galions
description:
Galions is a simultaneous play naval battle.

Each turn, at the same time all players decide which direction they want their ships to go.
You can decide to go loot merchandises that appeared in the sea at the beginning of the turn, go attack other players' boats, steer towards an island to buy and sell merchandises.
Then with money you can also buy new ships, build forts.

The first player to build his fifth fort wins the game.

—user summary

name: Astron
description:
This is a German Mah Jong version. The tiles consist of three suits (moon, sun, star) numbering 1-12 (3x), four temperaments (choleric/cock, sanguine/monkey, melancholy/owl, phlegmatic/turtle) and the four seasons (spring, summer, fall, winter). Of each tile there are three bits. Additionally there is one tile for each zodiac sign and each player color (red, blue, green, yellow). The color tiles are only used to randomly assign the player colors.
Two to four players take turns drawing from a stock (the wall), or from the other players' discards, in an attempt to form sets of numeric sequences of the same suit or trump tiles (temperaments, seasons, zodiac signs) to earn points.

At games end the player with the most points wins the game.

—user summary

name: Fore
description:
Fore is a golf game played on hand-made holes; the players need to draw the holes on one or two sheets each of lined paper according to the instructions. Pins or small markers are used to represent the balls.

Play is conducted using dice. Generally a player rolls three dice, one of which is a different color and determines the direction of the shot. The ball moves the total of the three dice in the air and then rolls an additional 50 yards. A player may choose to roll only one or two dice.

When in the approach area only one die is rolled and a chart is consulted, and there are additional rules for playing from the rough or a hazard.

name: Ricochet
description:
Ricochet is a race game played on the board shown, divided into rows with only a few ways to get from one to the next.

Each player has two pieces which start on the same space. On a turn a player rolls a die and moves one of their pieces accordingly. If it lands on a dot it moves through the opening to the next row. If it lands on an X the player loses their next turn.

If a piece encounters any other piece it ricochets and continues its movement back the way it came. However, it may not end up where it started the turn.

name: Passage
description:
Passage is a connection game played on a 20x20 square grid. Each player has an identical (except for color) set of polyominoes - three each of the seven shown. The pieces have semicircles along their edges.

Players are attempting to construct a path of their pieces between two opposite edges of the board. When pieces are next to each other their semicircles will join to form full circles. If a player can play a piece on top of an opposing piece so that at least two squares are covered and it forms more circles with adjacent pieces, the opposing piece is captured and replaced.

When a path between edges is formed (and can't be broken by an immediate capture) each player counts their longest path and the player with the longer one scores the difference. A series of games should be played to determine the overall winner.

The designer later (in Games & Puzzles #50) suggested playing with two copies of each piece instead, or using a 24x24 board.

name: Bone Strike
description:
Make no bone about it, Bone Strike will decimate your funny bone! Since the dawn of mankind, fighting for territory, resources, and hierarchy has been humanity's ridiculous struggle. In Bone Strike, amass an army of boneheaded warriors to battle your friends! Roll the bones to try your luck at conquering all. Strike while the iron is hot and pick a bone with this gut busting game bone-anza that will leave you laughing to your bones!

Bone Strike is a push your luck combat card game where you can continue to roll the dice as long as you do not bust out!

The object of bone strike is to remove your opponents' life points. This is done through damage rolled on combat dice. There are four different colors of dice in the game.

If any time dice are rolled and they score any symbols, add those symbols to your effect pool and you may choose to reroll any blanks. If all dice in play have added symbols to your dice pool, you may choose to reroll all of them. However, if any time dice are rolled and they do not score any symbols (rolls only blanks) remove all symbols in your effect pool, and the attack fails.

If you do not choose to reroll dice, the attack resolves. The warrior does damage to the target equal to the amount of damage symbols in their effect pool.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Push Your Luck

name: REACTOR IV
description:
"01:23 am. April 26, 1986. Prypiat, Ukraine. What will be one of the greatest nuclear catastrophes in history is unleashed. The workers at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant begin to do their work without really being aware of the dangers that lie ahead. Try to survive and receive as little radiation as possible.”

Reactor IV is a hidden role-playing game where players will try to survive the Chernobyl catastrophe. For this, the winner must have the minimum amount of radiation marker contamination points at the end of the game.

Players starts with 4 humanity markers and 10 radiation markers. During each round the players will select in a hidden way among the available characters to be able to interact with the other players and the different locations to exchange radiation markers. Another danger that will haunt players is death, which will come with 15 radiation markers.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hidden Roles, Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver

name: World War 2 Rules
description:
A fast moving 1925 to 1950 all arms set. Defeat the Nazis, Japs and Chinese. OK, you can defeat the Brits too, after all, they’ve lost everything since – well almost.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: 跡目の盃 (Atome no Sakazuki)
description:
跡目の盃 (Atome no Sakazuki) is a Japanese mafia game for 2 players only.

The theme is the tracing of the six Yakuza leaders. The player will be a child of any of these six and will strive to have his boss elected next president. Everything from a word that the other party says, to the action that got lost for a moment, is a psychological battle of batch bees that is a hint to win.

During the game you can feel the extraordinary tension, like the world of Yakuza. It is a game that you want to play with people who are close to each other and who know each other's personality. This game generally belongs to the genre called "identity concealment type game". For this reason, revealing your identity (who is the boss in this game) is synonymous with defeat in the game.

Actually, if the identity is out of the way, such as in a werewolf game, the game is not over immediately, but it will inevitably be at a disadvantage. And most of the information in this game is open. The information hidden by the opponent is only the main card of each other, and the contents of the hand are visible to each other until the end of the game.

Therefore, the important information is from "what to put out" to "a little action that I tried to put in this character for a moment". I want to raise the position of my boss, but the other party has the final say.

ヤクザの組長６人の跡目争いがテーマです。
プレイヤーはこれら６人の誰かの子分となって、自分の親分が次期会長に選ばれるよう尽力します。

相手が発した一言から、一瞬迷ったその所作まで、すべてが勝つためのヒントになるバッチバチの心理戦です。

ゲーム中はまさにヤクザの世界のような非日常的な緊張感が味わえます。

お互いの性格を知り尽くしているような親しい間柄の人とほど遊んで欲しいゲームです。

このゲームは一般的に「正体隠匿系ゲーム」というジャンルに属するゲームです。

そのため自分の正体（このゲームでは誰が親分か）がバレることはゲームにおける敗北と同義です。

実際は「人狼ゲーム」などのように正体がバレたら即ゲームオーバーというわけではないですが、それでも限りなく不利になることは変わりないでしょう。

そしてこのゲームはほとんどの情報がオープンです。
相手に隠されている情報はお互いの親分のみで、手札の内容もゲーム終了までお互いに見えています。

そのため「何を出すか」から「一瞬このキャラに置こうとして止めた」という、ちょっとした所作までが重要な情報となります。
publisher's summary
mechanics: Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Roles with Asymmetric Information

name: 蝉の声 (Cicada's Voice)
description:
蝉の声 (Semi no Koe) (Cicada's voice) is a Japanese card game, with players trying to mate Cicadas before children grab them.

user summary

name: Little Sweets Men
description:
リトル・スイーツ・メン (Little Sweets Men) is a Japanese card game. Made in a small quantity to be sold at Gamemarket as a test in 2017, the game is for three players only. The theme is strange little people who chase after sweets.

Each turn, one player is the parent and chooses which sweets will be up for claiming. The other players offer cards to claim the reward, at the risk of losing cards themselves. The way cards are lost depends on the sweets on offer. The idea is to control greed and gain a card that suits you.

user summary

name: Hexline
description:
Hexline is played on a triangular grid with three triangles to a side, but with only the vertices shown, not the lines. The rules say that each player gets 20 small sticks (e.g. matchsticks) to use, in different colors, but lines may simply be drawn in. A move is placing or drawing a line between two adjacent dots (vertices).

In each round one player attempts to make as long a continuous line as possible and the other player attempts to stop them. The linemaker plays first and afterwards must always play at one end of their line, unless a loop is formed with no ends in which case it may branch anywhere. The linemaker may never have more than two ends.

The other player may play on any open line segment.

When the linemaker can no longer play they score the number of lines they used and players swap roles.

name: Psychos & Slashers: Deluxe Set
description:
Psychos & Slashers is the ultimate game of recreational slaughter. It recreates the atmosphere of bad 'B' horror movies and lets players become their favorite victims while stalking innocent victims with handy tools and utensils. This combined set includes Suburban Slasher and Kamp Killjoy, which can be played separately or in combination.

—description from the publisher

name: Glasnost
description:
You play a Party member in a totalitarian regime facing grave crises. Each crisis can be resolved through reforms or repressions but each Party member has his or her own secret preferences.

Each Party member is either a Reformist, a Repressionist or a Nationalist. To win a ”Faction victory” for the Reformists or the Repressionists, you must name all your faction members (no more, no less). Failure to do so give the other faction a chance. Too many failures (depending on the player count) awards the Nationalists the victory.

If the game ends before a Faction victory, Party Members score VP for resolutions according to their personal preferences instead, e.g. Yeltsin wants to repress Economy and reform Security. The Party members with the most VP share a ”Personal victory”.

The players take turns to play the following phases:


Seat: Play a seat token next to two Crises.
Vote: If all seats are occupied, play a secret vote for a resolution (Reform/Repress a department).
Purge: If the vote is not unanimous, simul-taneously point out a Party member to purge and have his or her seat token removed.
Coup: Optionally stage coups by naming your faction members.


The game ends either through a Faction victory or if all seat tokens are played and/or all crises resolved, in which case a Personal victory decides the winners.

—description from the publisher

name: Dancing Dojos
description:
Dancing Dojos is a small, fast-paced set-collection card game by SCOTT JAMES BRITO of The Limestone Cowboy...

December 25th, 1854, 1 day after the devastating magnitude 8.4 Nankai and Tokai earthquakes. You and up to 4 four other friends will help the local sensei to rebuild their resepective dojos. Make the cards dance around the table as you draft them: sensei, spies, shuriken, flaming shuriken, walls, and temples. The first to build a sensei's dojo wins all glory!

During your turn, draft a card, perform an action, draft a 2nd card, and perform another action. Free actions may be performed unlimited times at any point during your turn.

To build a sensei’s dojo, collect a set of set of 4 cards matching the same suit. (Ex. 1 stone temple, 1 stone eastern wall, 1 stone western wall, and 1 stone sensei). Place them in their appropriate spaces within your 6 space, pyramid-shaped, player area.

In addition to set collection, each card type has a unique ability. For example, if you have a sensei in your play area, you may throw a shuriken (spend the shuriken by taping one of its corners on the opponent’s targeted card) do attack! Combine certain card types to unlock hidden abilities! Ex: Having the wood sensei and the wood temple allows you to search the discard pile for 1 wall card (once per turn). You may also strategically place cards face-down to keep a card safe, withhold it from an enemy, or even to set a trap!

—description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Fighting, Party Game, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Race, Set Collection, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Two-King Bagh Chal
description:
Per an article in Games & Puzzles #52, this is a traditional Nepalese game similar to Bagh Chal but played on a larger board with symmetric forces. The object is to capture the opposing king, capture all the opposing warriors, or block your opponent from moving.

A commercial version was published under the name Baazi which removes the kings but is otherwise identical.

name: Desertion
description:
A game similar to Checkers but played on a board with 10 rows of 4 points each (with two players) or a triangle with 9 points on a side (with three players). Players each have 12 double-sided pieces (with two) or 9 cubes (with three). Pieces move forwards and jump to capture; capturing is compulsory and multiple captures may be made.

A captured piece is not removed but instead flipped to display the capturing player's color.

A piece which reaches the opposite end of the board is immediately removed and is replaced on the near end of the board before the player's next turn (or as soon as there is a space for it).

If a player cannot move forwards they must more backwards without capturing. The game ends when one player cannot move at all or has no pieces.

name: Chasm Explorers
description:
Chasm Explorers was born in mid 2020 after several months of planning, wanting to bring video game mechanics like Diablo and Ultima Online to a board game. You can also use it as a rule system to build your own adventures.

"Look carefully, what an unusual sight: a nameless planet with a synchronous orbit around its star, perfectly divided in half, on one side the perennial frost, on the other a glowing desert. At the equator a series of small settlements united by narrow streets to the only immense city, called Pyraqva, dimly illuminated by an eternal dawn. And then there is the Chasm where the Castle once stood, a huge mouth from which emerge unclean screams and creatures that should not exist. After the "Great War" against "The Ancient Evil" and its armies, little remained of that splendid city, but a group of heroes wants to exterminate their enemy once and for all, crossing dangerous paths, corridors of the castle dungeons, immense ravines and enemies of all kinds, up to the last cave at the base of the Chasm, in search of revenge."

GAME MODES
CO-OP: If a player chooses to face the Dungeon alone he will use 2 characters, the party can have 4 characters in total: therefore 2 players can use one hero each, or 2 each ... Or 4 players each with their own character.
PVP: You choose a room (Arena) in which to fight, you can use the character from the "Adventure" or create one for this game mode, randomly distributing the abilities on your equipment, and perhaps some enemy that attacks on sight! You can have a number of players and heroes suited to your needs.

—description from the designer

name: Superfight: Holiday Challenge Pack
description:
Contains 25 Holiday-Themed Challenge Cards.

Draw one of these cards, then make your characters like you would in a regular game and argue over who would win that challenge!

Card List:

DELIVER THE MOST PRESENTS ON CHRISTMAS EVE
DRINK THE MOST EGGNOG
BEST MALL SANTA
DREIDEL
BEST HOST OF YOUR NEW YEAR'S COUNTDOWN PARTY
SAVE THE MOST HOSTAGES FROM NAKATOMI TOWER
SAVE CHRISTMAS FROM THE GRINCH
RECORD THE BEST HOLIDAY SINGLE
BUILD THE BEST SNOWMAN
BEST CHOICE TO LEAD SANTA'S SLEIGH ON ONE FOGGY CHRISTMAS EVE
MAKE THE MOST TOYS IN SANTA'S SWEATSHOP
UNDERSTAND THE TRUE MEANING OF THE HOLIDAYS
SCORE THE MOST DEALS ON BLACK FRIDAY
FASTEST PRESENT WRAPPER
HOLIDAY BAKING COMPETITION
MOST THOUGHTFUL GIFT-GIVER
DEFEAT KRAMPUS IN SINGLE COMBAT
SPREAD THE MOST HOLIDAY CHEER
RACE TO GRANDMOTHER'S HOUSE
SCARIEST GHOST OF CHRISTMAS FUTURE
BEST AT KEEPING NEW YEAR'S RESOLUTIONS
INFILTRATE THE NORTH POLE AND STEAL SANTA'S SLEIGH
SNOWBALL FIGHT
HAGGLE FOR A ROOM AT A CROWDED INN
MOST EXTREME SLEIGH DRIVER
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Humor, Party Game

name: Burtošanas čempionāts: pirmais paplašinājums
description: Expansion adds more syllables, and also tasks and opportunity cards. Playing with the extension, you will be able to create even more than 20,000 long-forgotten or very modern words in Latvian.
categories: Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Word Game

name: Table Air Combat: Ki-44 Tojo
description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
All you need are some six-sided dice and some coins to provide weight for the aircraft counters.
Everything else can be printed from this ruleset.

Each player has a flight of four aircraft represented by two counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.

A performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.

TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag.
Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

Ki-44 Shoki was a high-altitude interceptor with an excellent climb rate.
Self-sealing fuel tanks and a radial engine made it tough compared with other Japanese aircraft, but it suffered from weak armament of just four 12.7mm machine guns.

This set is a self-contained rulebook with miniatures for the Ki-44 Tojo and three scenarios that reference other aircraft.


Sho-Go: US Navy attacks Japanese-held airfield on Formosa island. Ki-44s defend against F6F Hellcat fighter-bombers.
Meridian: Royal Navy Hellcats and Avengers attack Japanese oil refineries in Sumatra. The Japanese Army Air Force defends with Ki-44s
Otsu: A variant of the Ki-44 uses 40mm cannons to intercept a formation of B-29 Superfortress bombers.


This set contains miniatures for the Ki-44.

Other aircraft must be purchased separately.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Factory 17: A New Location for Five Klicks From the Zone
description:
The second supplement for Five Klicks adds a new location to explore: A monster infested factory full of toxic waste, genetic abnormalities and impenetrable gloom.

This location can be added to any on-going campaign and offers a somewhat tougher experience.

6 new enemies to fight, each with a special rule to make things interesting.
6 new "special conditions" to make the battle field a more dangerous or unpredictable place.
6 new items to acquire for your squad, 5 of them being unique and the last being a nice stash of things that go boom.


The location can be dropped into your existing campaign without having to restart and can be visited multiple times (6 in fact!).

You will need the main Five Klicks skirmish rules to use this pack.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Summit
description:
Summit is played on a 4x4 grid, although larger boards are suggested as a variant. Players take turns writing numbers in empty spaces; each player will end up writing the numbers from 1-8.

After all spaces are filled one player will score the rows and the other the columns; in each case the score is the absolute difference between the total and 18.

Symmetric play is prohibited by a rule requiring no diagonal symmetry after both players have taken three turns.

name: Motor Speed
description:
Motor Speed is a somewhat more complex take on the idea of Racetrack. Instead of drawing lines, players move tokens representing cars on a square grid track.

As in Racetrack cars use vector movement and can generally only alter each component of the vector (horizontal and vertical) by one space a turn.
